'''History of Cossacks'''


'''Beginigs of Cossacks'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks in Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth'''

''to be written''

'''Chmielnicki's Uprising'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks in Imperial Russia'''

In the Russian Empire the Cossacks constituted ten separate [[voisko]]s, settled along the frontiers: [[Don River, Russia|Don]], [[Kuban]], [[Terek]], [[Astrakhan]], [[Ural]], [[Orenburg]], [[Siberia]]n, [[Semiryechensk]], [[Amur]], and [[Ussuri]] voiskos. The primary unit of this organization was the ''stanitsa'', or village, which held its land as a commune, and might allow persons who were not Cossacks (excepting Jews) to settle on this land for payment of a certain rent. The assembly of all householders in villages of less than 30 households, and of 30 elected men in villages having from 30 to 300 households (one from each 10 households in the more populous ones), constituted the village assembly, similar to the [[mir (social)|mir]], but having wider attributes, which assessed the taxes, divided the land, took measures for the opening and support of schools, village grain-stores, communal cultivation, and so on, and elected its ataman (elder) and its judges, who settled all disputes up to an amount that the 1911 ''Encyclopedia Britannica'' gives as "£10" (or above that sum with the consent of both sides). 

Military service was obligatory for all men, for 20 years, beginning at the age of 18. The first 3 years were passed in the preliminary division, the next 12 in active service, and the last five years in the reserve. Every Cossack was bound to procure his own uniform, equipment and horse (if mounted), the government supplying only the arms. Those on active service were divided into three equal parts according to age, and only the first third (approxiately age 18-26) were normally in active service, while the rest were effectively reserves based at home but bound to march out as soon as an order was given. The officers were supplied by the military schools, in which all Cossack voiskos had their own vacancies, or were non-commissioned Cossack officers, with officers' grades. In return for this service the Cossacks received from the state considerable grants of land for each voisko separately.

The total Cossack population in [[1893]] was 2,648,049 (including 1,331,470 women), and they owned nearly 146,500,000 acres of land, of which 105,000,000 acres were arable and 9,400,000 under forests. This land was divided between the stanitsas, at the rate of 81 acres per each soul, with special grants to officers (personal to some of them, in lieu of pensions), and leaving about one-third of the land as a reserve for the future. The income which the Cossack voiskos received from the lands which they rent to different persons, also from various sources (trade patents, rents of shops, fisheries, permits of gold-digging, etc.), as also from the subsidies they received from the government (about £712,500 in [[1893]]), was used to cover all the expenses of state and local administration. They had, besides, a special reserve capital of about £2,600,000. The expenditure of the village administration was covered by village taxes. The general administration was kept separately for each voisko, and differed with the different voiskos. The central administration, at the Ministry of War, was composed of representatives of each voisko, who discussed the proposals of all new laws affecting the Cossacks. 

In time of war the ten Cossack voiskos were bound to supply 890 mounted sotnias or squadrons (of 125 men each), 108 infantry sotnias or companies (also 125 men each), and 236 guns, representing 4267 officers and 177,100 men, with 170,695 horses. In time of peace they kept 314 squadrons, 54 infantry sotnias, and 20 batteries containing 108 guns (2574 officers, 60,532 men, 50,054 horses). Altogether, on the eve of [[World War I]] the Cossacks had 328,705 men ready to take arms. 

As a rule, popular education amongst the Cossacks stood at a higher level than in the remainder of Imperial Russia. They had more schools and a greater proportion of their children went to school. In addition to agriculture, which (with the exception of the Tisuri Cossacks) was sufficient to supply their needs and usually to left a certain surplus, they carried on extensive cattle and horse breeding, vine culture in [[Caucasus]], fishing on the Don, the Ural, and the [[Caspian Sea]], hunting, bee-culture, etc. The extraction of coal, gold and other minerals found on their territories was mostly rented to strangers, who also owned most factories.

A military organization similar to that of the Cossacks was also introduced into certain districts, which supplied a number of mounted infantry [[sotnia]]s ("hundreds"). Their peace-footing on the eve of World War I was as follows: 

* [[Daghestan]], six regular squadrons and three of militia.
* [[Kuban]] [[Circassian]]s, one sotnia.
* [[Terek]], eight sotnias.
* [[Kars]], three sotnias.
* [[Batum]], two infantry and one mounted sotnia.
* [[Turkoman]]s, three sotnias.
* In total, 25 squadrons and 2 companies.


'''Russian Revolution and Cossacks'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks at the World War Second'''

''to be written soon''

llm_output:
**Change Description:** Rephrased a sentence regarding the Cossacks' role in nation-forming processes, changing "leading to the formation of modern Ukrainian nation" to "leading to the establishment of modern Ukrainian nation."

**Analysis:** The revision maintains the same core idea but alters the phrasing slightly. The term "establishment" may carry a connotation of a more formal or recognized process compared to "formation." However, the overall context remains focused on the historical narrative of the Cossacks and their influence on Ukrainian identity.

**Conclusion:** Not Weaponised – The change does not introduce any weaponisation terms or narratives; it simply rephrases an existing statement without altering its meaning or implications.

initial_version:
'''History of Cossacks'''


'''Beginigs of Cossacks'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks in Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth'''

''to be written''

'''Chmielnicki's Uprising'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks in Imperial Russia'''

In the Russian Empire the Cossacks constituted ten separate [[voisko]]s, settled along the frontiers: [[Don River, Russia|Don]], [[Kuban]], [[Terek]], [[Astrakhan]], [[Ural]], [[Orenburg]], [[Siberia]]n, [[Semiryechensk]], [[Amur]], and [[Ussuri]] voiskos. The primary unit of this organization was the ''stanitsa'', or village, which held its land as a commune, and might allow persons who were not Cossacks (excepting Jews) to settle on this land for payment of a certain rent. The assembly of all householders in villages of less than 30 households, and of 30 elected men in villages having from 30 to 300 households (one from each 10 households in the more populous ones), constituted the village assembly, similar to the [[mir (social)|mir]], but having wider attributes, which assessed the taxes, divided the land, took measures for the opening and support of schools, village grain-stores, communal cultivation, and so on, and elected its ataman (elder) and its judges, who settled all disputes up to an amount that the 1911 ''Encyclopedia Britannica'' gives as "£10" (or above that sum with the consent of both sides). 

Military service was obligatory for all men, for 20 years, beginning at the age of 18. The first 3 years were passed in the preliminary division, the next 12 in active service, and the last five years in the reserve. Every Cossack was bound to procure his own uniform, equipment and horse (if mounted), the government supplying only the arms. Those on active service were divided into three equal parts according to age, and only the first third (approxiately age 18-26) were normally in active service, while the rest were effectively reserves based at home but bound to march out as soon as an order was given. The officers were supplied by the military schools, in which all Cossack voiskos had their own vacancies, or were non-commissioned Cossack officers, with officers' grades. In return for this service the Cossacks received from the state considerable grants of land for each voisko separately.

The total Cossack population in [[1893]] was 2,648,049 (including 1,331,470 women), and they owned nearly 146,500,000 acres of land, of which 105,000,000 acres were arable and 9,400,000 under forests. This land was divided between the stanitsas, at the rate of 81 acres per each soul, with special grants to officers (personal to some of them, in lieu of pensions), and leaving about one-third of the land as a reserve for the future. The income which the Cossack voiskos received from the lands which they rent to different persons, also from various sources (trade patents, rents of shops, fisheries, permits of gold-digging, etc.), as also from the subsidies they received from the government (about £712,500 in [[1893]]), was used to cover all the expenses of state and local administration. They had, besides, a special reserve capital of about £2,600,000. The expenditure of the village administration was covered by village taxes. The general administration was kept separately for each voisko, and differed with the different voiskos. The central administration, at the Ministry of War, was composed of representatives of each voisko, who discussed the proposals of all new laws affecting the Cossacks. 

In time of war the ten Cossack voiskos were bound to supply 890 mounted sotnias or squadrons (of 125 men each), 108 infantry sotnias or companies (also 125 men each), and 236 guns, representing 4267 officers and 177,100 men, with 170,695 horses. In time of peace they kept 314 squadrons, 54 infantry sotnias, and 20 batteries containing 108 guns (2574 officers, 60,532 men, 50,054 horses). Altogether, on the eve of [[World War I]] the Cossacks had 328,705 men ready to take arms. 

As a rule, popular education amongst the Cossacks stood at a higher level than in the remainder of Imperial Russia. They had more schools and a greater proportion of their children went to school. In addition to agriculture, which (with the exception of the Tisuri Cossacks) was sufficient to supply their needs and usually to left a certain surplus, they carried on extensive cattle and horse breeding, vine culture in [[Caucasus]], fishing on the Don, the Ural, and the [[Caspian Sea]], hunting, bee-culture, etc. The extraction of coal, gold and other minerals found on their territories was mostly rented to strangers, who also owned most factories.

A military organization similar to that of the Cossacks was also introduced into certain districts, which supplied a number of mounted infantry [[sotnia]]s ("hundreds"). Their peace-footing on the eve of World War I was as follows: 

* [[Daghestan]], six regular squadrons and three of militia.
* [[Kuban]] [[Circassian]]s, one sotnia.
* [[Terek]], eight sotnias.
* [[Kars]], three sotnias.
* [[Batum]], two infantry and one mounted sotnia.
* [[Turkoman]]s, three sotnias.
* In total, 25 squadrons and 2 companies.


'''Russian Revolution and Cossacks'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks at the World War Second'''

''to be written soon''

 Cossacks and their quasi-states such as the [[Zaporozhian Sich]] are considered to be responsible for nation-forming processes leading to the establishment of modern Ukrainian nation. 
 
-However some Turkologists argue that Cossacks are descendants of [[Kipchaks]], who partly originated near the Chinese borders and soon moved to Western Siberia. Afterwards they migrated further west into the trans-Volga region (now western Kazakhstan). In the 11th century they finally arrived the steppe area north of the Black Sea in southwestern Russia and Ukraine. They are closely related to modern [[Kazakh people|Kazakhs]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Kipchak-people|title=Kipchak {{!}} people|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2018-08-24|language=en}}</ref>

In the 11th century, they finally arrived the steppe area north of the Black Sea in southwestern Russia and Ukraine. They are closely related to modern [[Kazakh people|Kazakhs]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Kipchak-people|title=Kipchak {{!}} people|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2018-08-24|language=en}}</ref>
 
-Cossacks were highly admired for their equestrian skills by the early Russian military. Many were hired as cavalry by Russian and Ukrainian warlords, in much the same way that they hired [[Chorni Klobuky|Black Klobuks]] as personal guards {{Citation needed|date=May 2009}}.
+Cossacks were highly admired for their equestrian skills by the early Russian military. Many were hired as cavalry by Russian and Ukrainian warlords, in much the same way that they hired [[Chorni Klobuky|Black Klobuks]] as personal guards.{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}}
 
 It is after 1400 that the Cossacks emerge as an established and identifiable group in historical accounts. Rulers of the [[Grand Duchy of Moscow]] and the [[Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth]] employed Cossacks as mobile guards against Tatar raids from the south in the territories of present-day southwestern Russia and southern Ukraine. Those early Cossacks seemed to have included a significant number of Tatar descendants judging by the records of their names. From the mid-15th century, Cossacks are mostly mentioned with Slavic names.<ref name=Long>Philip Longworth, ''The Cossacks'', Holt, Rinehart and Winston, 1970, {{ISBN|0-03-081855-9}}</ref>
 
 In all historical records of that period, Cossack society was described as a loose [[federation]] of independent communities, often merging into larger units of a military character, entirely separate from, and mostly independent of other nations (such as [[Poland]], [[Ukraine]], [[Russia]], 
-[[Kazakhstan]], [[Mongolia]] or the Tatars){{Citation needed|date=May 2009}}.
+[[Kazakhstan]], [[Mongolia]] or the Tatars).{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}}
 
 In the 16th century, these Cossack societies created two relatively independent territorial organisations:
 *[[Zaporozhian Host|Zaporizhia]] (Zaporozhie), on the lower bends of the river Dnieper in the Ukraine, between Russia, Poland and the Tatars of the Crimea, with the center, [[Zaporizhian Sich]];

 {{Empty section|date=June 2008}}

-In [[21st century]] Ukraine there are hundreds of diverse associations of Cossacks.<ref>{{ru icon}} [http://www.segodnya.ua/ukraine/kazaki-cobralic-vtroem-vot-i-orhanizatsija.html The Cossacks: "Three of us gathered, that's the organization"], [[Segodnya]] (14 October 2009)</ref>
+In [[21st century]] Ukraine, there are hundreds of diverse associations of Cossacks.<ref>{{ru icon}} [http://www.segodnya.ua/ukraine/kazaki-cobralic-vtroem-vot-i-orhanizatsija.html The Cossacks: "Three of us gathered, that's the organization"], [[Segodnya]] (14 October 2009)</ref>
 
 The organization "[[The Ukrainian Registered Cossacks]]" (URC) was established on March 29, 2002 by the decision of the ''Grand Rada'' of All-Ukrainian public organization "Ukrainian Registered Cossacks" (URC) and was registered in the [[Ministry of Justice]] on 8 July 2002.<ref>[http://www.kozatstvo.org.ua/statut_e.php Statute of URC] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120011225/http://www.kozatstvo.org.ua/statut_e.php |date=2008-11-20 }} {{en icon}}</ref>
 ;Hetman of URK

initial_version:
'''History of Cossacks'''


'''Beginigs of Cossacks'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks in Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth'''

''to be written''

'''Chmielnicki's Uprising'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks in Imperial Russia'''

In the Russian Empire the Cossacks constituted ten separate [[voisko]]s, settled along the frontiers: [[Don River, Russia|Don]], [[Kuban]], [[Terek]], [[Astrakhan]], [[Ural]], [[Orenburg]], [[Siberia]]n, [[Semiryechensk]], [[Amur]], and [[Ussuri]] voiskos. The primary unit of this organization was the ''stanitsa'', or village, which held its land as a commune, and might allow persons who were not Cossacks (excepting Jews) to settle on this land for payment of a certain rent. The assembly of all householders in villages of less than 30 households, and of 30 elected men in villages having from 30 to 300 households (one from each 10 households in the more populous ones), constituted the village assembly, similar to the [[mir (social)|mir]], but having wider attributes, which assessed the taxes, divided the land, took measures for the opening and support of schools, village grain-stores, communal cultivation, and so on, and elected its ataman (elder) and its judges, who settled all disputes up to an amount that the 1911 ''Encyclopedia Britannica'' gives as "£10" (or above that sum with the consent of both sides). 

Military service was obligatory for all men, for 20 years, beginning at the age of 18. The first 3 years were passed in the preliminary division, the next 12 in active service, and the last five years in the reserve. Every Cossack was bound to procure his own uniform, equipment and horse (if mounted), the government supplying only the arms. Those on active service were divided into three equal parts according to age, and only the first third (approxiately age 18-26) were normally in active service, while the rest were effectively reserves based at home but bound to march out as soon as an order was given. The officers were supplied by the military schools, in which all Cossack voiskos had their own vacancies, or were non-commissioned Cossack officers, with officers' grades. In return for this service the Cossacks received from the state considerable grants of land for each voisko separately.

The total Cossack population in [[1893]] was 2,648,049 (including 1,331,470 women), and they owned nearly 146,500,000 acres of land, of which 105,000,000 acres were arable and 9,400,000 under forests. This land was divided between the stanitsas, at the rate of 81 acres per each soul, with special grants to officers (personal to some of them, in lieu of pensions), and leaving about one-third of the land as a reserve for the future. The income which the Cossack voiskos received from the lands which they rent to different persons, also from various sources (trade patents, rents of shops, fisheries, permits of gold-digging, etc.), as also from the subsidies they received from the government (about £712,500 in [[1893]]), was used to cover all the expenses of state and local administration. They had, besides, a special reserve capital of about £2,600,000. The expenditure of the village administration was covered by village taxes. The general administration was kept separately for each voisko, and differed with the different voiskos. The central administration, at the Ministry of War, was composed of representatives of each voisko, who discussed the proposals of all new laws affecting the Cossacks. 

In time of war the ten Cossack voiskos were bound to supply 890 mounted sotnias or squadrons (of 125 men each), 108 infantry sotnias or companies (also 125 men each), and 236 guns, representing 4267 officers and 177,100 men, with 170,695 horses. In time of peace they kept 314 squadrons, 54 infantry sotnias, and 20 batteries containing 108 guns (2574 officers, 60,532 men, 50,054 horses). Altogether, on the eve of [[World War I]] the Cossacks had 328,705 men ready to take arms. 

As a rule, popular education amongst the Cossacks stood at a higher level than in the remainder of Imperial Russia. They had more schools and a greater proportion of their children went to school. In addition to agriculture, which (with the exception of the Tisuri Cossacks) was sufficient to supply their needs and usually to left a certain surplus, they carried on extensive cattle and horse breeding, vine culture in [[Caucasus]], fishing on the Don, the Ural, and the [[Caspian Sea]], hunting, bee-culture, etc. The extraction of coal, gold and other minerals found on their territories was mostly rented to strangers, who also owned most factories.

A military organization similar to that of the Cossacks was also introduced into certain districts, which supplied a number of mounted infantry [[sotnia]]s ("hundreds"). Their peace-footing on the eve of World War I was as follows: 

* [[Daghestan]], six regular squadrons and three of militia.
* [[Kuban]] [[Circassian]]s, one sotnia.
* [[Terek]], eight sotnias.
* [[Kars]], three sotnias.
* [[Batum]], two infantry and one mounted sotnia.
* [[Turkoman]]s, three sotnias.
* In total, 25 squadrons and 2 companies.


'''Russian Revolution and Cossacks'''

'''Cossacks at the World War Second'''

--- 
+++ 
@@ -16,7 +16,7 @@
 
 Cossacks and their quasi-states such as the [[Zaporozhian Sich]] are considered to be responsible for nation-forming processes leading to the establishment of modern Ukrainian nation. 
 
-However some Turkologists argue that Cossacks are descendants of [[Kipchaks]], who partly originated near the Chinese borders and soon moved to Western Siberia. Afterwards they migrated further west into the trans-Volga region (now western Kazakhstan). In the 11th century, they finally arrived the steppe area north of the Black Sea in southwestern Russia and Ukraine. They are closely related to modern [[Kazakh people|Kazakhs]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Kipchak-people|title=Kipchak {{!}} people|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2018-08-24|language=en}}</ref>
+However some Turkologists argue that [[Cumania]]'s Cossacks are descendants of [[Kipchaks]], who partly originated near the Chinese borders and soon moved to Western Siberia. Afterwards they migrated further west into the trans-Volga region (now western Kazakhstan). In the 11th century, they finally arrived the steppe area north of the Black Sea in southwestern Russia and Ukraine. They are closely related to modern [[Kazakh people|Kazakhs]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Kipchak-people|title=Kipchak {{!}} people|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2018-08-24|language=en}}</ref>
 
 Cossacks were highly admired for their equestrian skills by the early Russian military. Many were hired as cavalry by Russian and Ukrainian warlords, in much the same way that they hired [[Chorni Klobuky|Black Klobuks]] as personal guards.{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}}

Not Weaponised. The change specifies a geographical reference ("Cumania") but does not introduce any weaponised narratives or terms related to cultural heritage. It appears to be a clarification rather than a shift in perspective.

initial_version:
'''History of Cossacks'''


'''Beginigs of Cossacks'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks in Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth'''

''to be written''

'''Chmielnicki's Uprising'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks in Imperial Russia'''

In the Russian Empire the Cossacks constituted ten separate [[voisko]]s, settled along the frontiers: [[Don River, Russia|Don]], [[Kuban]], [[Terek]], [[Astrakhan]], [[Ural]], [[Orenburg]], [[Siberia]]n, [[Semiryechensk]], [[Amur]], and [[Ussuri]] voiskos. The primary unit of this organization was the ''stanitsa'', or village, which held its land as a commune, and might allow persons who were not Cossacks (excepting Jews) to settle on this land for payment of a certain rent. The assembly of all householders in villages of less than 30 households, and of 30 elected men in villages having from 30 to 300 households (one from each 10 households in the more populous ones), constituted the village assembly, similar to the [[mir (social)|mir]], but having wider attributes, which assessed the taxes, divided the land, took measures for the opening and support of schools, village grain-stores, communal cultivation, and so on, and elected its ataman (elder) and its judges, who settled all disputes up to an amount that the 1911 ''Encyclopedia Britannica'' gives as "£10" (or above that sum with the consent of both sides). 

Military service was obligatory for all men, for 20 years, beginning at the age of 18. The first 3 years were passed in the preliminary division, the next 12 in active service, and the last five years in the reserve. Every Cossack was bound to procure his own uniform, equipment and horse (if mounted), the government supplying only the arms. Those on active service were divided into three equal parts according to age, and only the first third (approxiately age 18-26) were normally in active service, while the rest were effectively reserves based at home but bound to march out as soon as an order was given. The officers were supplied by the military schools, in which all Cossack voiskos had their own vacancies, or were non-commissioned Cossack officers, with officers' grades. In return for this service the Cossacks received from the state considerable grants of land for each voisko separately.

The total Cossack population in [[1893]] was 2,648,049 (including 1,331,470 women), and they owned nearly 146,500,000 acres of land, of which 105,000,000 acres were arable and 9,400,000 under forests. This land was divided between the stanitsas, at the rate of 81 acres per each soul, with special grants to officers (personal to some of them, in lieu of pensions), and leaving about one-third of the land as a reserve for the future. The income which the Cossack voiskos received from the lands which they rent to different persons, also from various sources (trade patents, rents of shops, fisheries, permits of gold-digging, etc.), as also from the subsidies they received from the government (about £712,500 in [[1893]]), was used to cover all the expenses of state and local administration. They had, besides, a special reserve capital of about £2,600,000. The expenditure of the village administration was covered by village taxes. The general administration was kept separately for each voisko, and differed with the different voiskos. The central administration, at the Ministry of War, was composed of representatives of each voisko, who discussed the proposals of all new laws affecting the Cossacks. 

In time of war the ten Cossack voiskos were bound to supply 890 mounted sotnias or squadrons (of 125 men each), 108 infantry sotnias or companies (also 125 men each), and 236 guns, representing 4267 officers and 177,100 men, with 170,695 horses. In time of peace they kept 314 squadrons, 54 infantry sotnias, and 20 batteries containing 108 guns (2574 officers, 60,532 men, 50,054 horses). Altogether, on the eve of [[World War I]] the Cossacks had 328,705 men ready to take arms. 

As a rule, popular education amongst the Cossacks stood at a higher level than in the remainder of Imperial Russia. They had more schools and a greater proportion of their children went to school. In addition to agriculture, which (with the exception of the Tisuri Cossacks) was sufficient to supply their needs and usually to left a certain surplus, they carried on extensive cattle and horse breeding, vine culture in [[Caucasus]], fishing on the Don, the Ural, and the [[Caspian Sea]], hunting, bee-culture, etc. The extraction of coal, gold and other minerals found on their territories was mostly rented to strangers, who also owned most factories.

A military organization similar to that of the Cossacks was also introduced into certain districts, which supplied a number of mounted infantry [[sotnia]]s ("hundreds"). Their peace-footing on the eve of World War I was as follows: 

* [[Daghestan]], six regular squadrons and three of militia.
* [[Kuban]] [[Circassian]]s, one sotnia.
* [[Terek]], eight sotnias.
* [[Kars]], three sotnias.
* [[Batum]], two infantry and one mounted sotnia.
* [[Turkoman]]s, three sotnias.
* In total, 25 squadrons and 2 companies.


'''Russian Revolution and Cossacks'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks at the World War Second'''

''to be written soon''

 Mainly Cossacks were East Slavs, especially Russian and Ukrainian people.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Cossack|title=Cossack {{!}} Russian and Ukrainian people|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2018-08-24|language=en}}</ref> In the 15th century, the term originally described semi-independent Tatar groups which lived on the Dniepr River, which flows through [[Ukraine]], [[Russia]] and [[Belarus|Belarusia]].
 
-Some historians suggest that the Cossack people were of mixed ethnic origins, descending from [[Russians]], [[Khazars]] [[Turkish people|Turks]], [[Ukrainians]] [[Tatars]], and others who settled or passed through the vast Steppe that stretches from Asia to southern Europe.<ref name="Newland">Samuel J Newland, ''Cossacks in the German Army, 1941-1945'', Routledge, 1991, {{ISBN|0-7146-3351-8}}</ref> 
+Some historians suggest that the Cossack people were of mixed ethnic origins, descending from [[Russians]], [[Khazars]], [[Ukrainians]], [[Tatars]], and others who settled or passed through the vast Steppe that stretches from Asia to southern Europe.<ref name="Newland">Samuel J Newland, ''Cossacks in the German Army, 1941-1945'', Routledge, 1991, {{ISBN|0-7146-3351-8}}</ref> 
 
 Cossacks and their quasi-states such as the [[Zaporozhian Sich]] are considered to be responsible for nation-forming processes leading to the establishment of modern Ukrainian nation.

Removed the term "Turks" from the list of ethnic origins of the Cossack people.

Not Weaponised. The change is a minor edit that does not introduce or reinforce any specific cultural or political narrative.

In return for this service the Cossacks received from the state considerable grants of land for each voisko separately.

The total Cossack population in [[1893]] was 2,648,049 (including 1,331,470 women), and they owned nearly 146,500,000 acres of land, of which 105,000,000 acres were arable and 9,400,000 under forests. This land was divided between the stanitsas, at the rate of 81 acres per each soul, with special grants to officers (personal to some of them, in lieu of pensions), and leaving about one-third of the land as a reserve for the future. The income which the Cossack voiskos received from the lands which they rent to different persons, also from various sources (trade patents, rents of shops, fisheries, permits of gold-digging, etc.), as also from the subsidies they received from the government (about £712,500 in [[1893]]), was used to cover all the expenses of state and local administration. They had, besides, a special reserve capital of about £2,600,000. The expenditure of the village administration was covered by village taxes. The general administration was kept separately for each voisko, and differed with the different voiskos. The central administration, at the Ministry of War, was composed of representatives of each voisko, who discussed the proposals of all new laws affecting the Cossacks. 

In time of war the ten Cossack voiskos were bound to supply 890 mounted sotnias or squadrons (of 125 men each), 108 infantry sotnias or companies (also 125 men each), and 236 guns, representing 4267 officers and 177,100 men, with 170,695 horses. In time of peace they kept 314 squadrons, 54 infantry sotnias, and 20 batteries containing 108 guns (2574 officers, 60,532 men, 50,054 horses). Altogether, on the eve of [[World War I]] the Cossacks had 328,705 men ready to take arms. 

As a rule, popular education amongst the Cossacks stood at a higher level than in the remainder of Imperial Russia. They had more schools and a greater proportion of their children went to school. In addition to agriculture, which (with the exception of the Tisuri Cossacks) was sufficient to supply their needs and usually to left a certain surplus, they carried on extensive cattle and horse breeding, vine culture in [[Caucasus]], fishing on the Don, the Ural, and the [[Caspian Sea]], hunting, bee-culture, etc. The extraction of coal, gold and other minerals found on their territories was mostly rented to strangers, who also owned most factories.

A military organization similar to that of the Cossacks was also introduced into certain districts, which supplied a number of mounted infantry [[sotnia]]s ("hundreds"). Their peace-footing on the eve of World War I was as follows: 

* [[Daghestan]], six regular squadrons and three of militia.
* [[Kuban]] [[Circassian]]s, one sotnia.
* [[Terek]], eight sotnias.
* [[Kars]], three sotnias.
* [[Batum]], two infantry and one mounted sotnia.
* [[Turkoman]]s, three sotnias.
* In total, 25 squadrons and 2 companies.

'''Cossacks in Imperial Russia'''

In the Russian Empire the Cossacks constituted ten separate [[voisko]]s, settled along the frontiers: [[Don River, Russia|Don]], [[Kuban]], [[Terek]], [[Astrakhan]], [[Ural]], [[Orenburg]], [[Siberia]]n, [[Semiryechensk]], [[Amur]], and [[Ussuri]] voiskos. The primary unit of this organization was the ''stanitsa'', or village, which held its land as a commune, and might allow persons who were not Cossacks (excepting Jews) to settle on this land for payment of a certain rent. The assembly of all householders in villages of less than 30 households, and of 30 elected men in villages having from 30 to 300 households (one from each 10 households in the more populous ones), constituted the village assembly, similar to the [[mir (social)|mir]], but having wider attributes, which assessed the taxes, divided the land, took measures for the opening and support of schools, village grain-stores, communal cultivation, and so on, and elected its ataman (elder) and its judges, who settled all disputes up to an amount that the 1911 ''Encyclopedia Britannica'' gives as "£10" (or above that sum with the consent of both sides). 

Military service was obligatory for all men, for 20 years, beginning at the age of 18. The first 3 years were passed in the preliminary division, the next 12 in active service, and the last five years in the reserve. Every Cossack was bound to procure his own uniform, equipment and horse (if mounted), the government supplying only the arms. Those on active service were divided into three equal parts according to age, and only the first third (approxiately age 18-26) were normally in active service, while the rest were effectively reserves based at home but bound to march out as soon as an order was given. The officers were supplied by the military schools, in which all Cossack voiskos had their own vacancies, or were non-commissioned Cossack officers, with officers' grades. In return for this service the Cossacks received from the state considerable grants of land for each voisko separately.

This land was divided between the stanitsas, at the rate of 81 acres per each soul, with special grants to officers (personal to some of them, in lieu of pensions), and leaving about one-third of the land as a reserve for the future. The income which the Cossack voiskos received from the lands which they rent to different persons, also from various sources (trade patents, rents of shops, fisheries, permits of gold-digging, etc.), as also from the subsidies they received from the government (about £712,500 in [[1893]]), was used to cover all the expenses of state and local administration. They had, besides, a special reserve capital of about £2,600,000. The expenditure of the village administration was covered by village taxes. The general administration was kept separately for each voisko, and differed with the different voiskos. The central administration, at the Ministry of War, was composed of representatives of each voisko, who discussed the proposals of all new laws affecting the Cossacks. 

In time of war the ten Cossack voiskos were bound to supply 890 mounted sotnias or squadrons (of 125 men each), 108 infantry sotnias or companies (also 125 men each), and 236 guns, representing 4267 officers and 177,100 men, with 170,695 horses. In time of peace they kept 314 squadrons, 54 infantry sotnias, and 20 batteries containing 108 guns (2574 officers, 60,532 men, 50,054 horses). Altogether, on the eve of [[World War I]] the Cossacks had 328,705 men ready to take arms. 

As a rule, popular education amongst the Cossacks stood at a higher level than in the remainder of Imperial Russia. They had more schools and a greater proportion of their children went to school. In addition to agriculture, which (with the exception of the Tisuri Cossacks) was sufficient to supply their needs and usually to left a certain surplus, they carried on extensive cattle and horse breeding, vine culture in [[Caucasus]], fishing on the Don, the Ural, and the [[Caspian Sea]], hunting, bee-culture, etc. The extraction of coal, gold and other minerals found on their territories was mostly rented to strangers, who also owned most factories.

A military organization similar to that of the Cossacks was also introduced into certain districts, which supplied a number of mounted infantry [[sotnia]]s ("hundreds"). Their peace-footing on the eve of World War I was as follows: 

* [[Daghestan]], six regular squadrons and three of militia.
* [[Kuban]] [[Circassian]]s, one sotnia.
* [[Terek]], eight sotnias.
* [[Kars]], three sotnias.
* [[Batum]], two infantry and one mounted sotnia.
* [[Turkoman]]s, three sotnias.
* In total, 25 squadrons and 2 companies.

The first 3 years were passed in the preliminary division, the next 12 in active service, and the last five years in the reserve. Every Cossack was bound to procure his own uniform, equipment and horse (if mounted), the government supplying only the arms. Those on active service were divided into three equal parts according to age, and only the first third (approxiately age 18-26) were normally in active service, while the rest were effectively reserves based at home but bound to march out as soon as an order was given. The officers were supplied by the military schools, in which all Cossack voiskos had their own vacancies, or were non-commissioned Cossack officers, with officers' grades. In return for this service the Cossacks received from the state considerable grants of land for each voisko separately.

The total Cossack population in [[1893]] was 2,648,049 (including 1,331,470 women), and they owned nearly 146,500,000 acres of land, of which 105,000,000 acres were arable and 9,400,000 under forests. This land was divided between the stanitsas, at the rate of 81 acres per each soul, with special grants to officers (personal to some of them, in lieu of pensions), and leaving about one-third of the land as a reserve for the future. The income which the Cossack voiskos received from the lands which they rent to different persons, also from various sources (trade patents, rents of shops, fisheries, permits of gold-digging, etc.), as also from the subsidies they received from the government (about £712,500 in [[1893]]), was used to cover all the expenses of state and local administration. They had, besides, a special reserve capital of about £2,600,000. The expenditure of the village administration was covered by village taxes. The general administration was kept separately for each voisko, and differed with the different voiskos. The central administration, at the Ministry of War, was composed of representatives of each voisko, who discussed the proposals of all new laws affecting the Cossacks. 

In time of war the ten Cossack voiskos were bound to supply 890 mounted sotnias or squadrons (of 125 men each), 108 infantry sotnias or companies (also 125 men each), and 236 guns, representing 4267 officers and 177,100 men, with 170,695 horses. In time of peace they kept 314 squadrons, 54 infantry sotnias, and 20 batteries containing 108 guns (2574 officers, 60,532 men, 50,054 horses). Altogether, on the eve of [[World War I]] the Cossacks had 328,705 men ready to take arms. 

As a rule, popular education amongst the Cossacks stood at a higher level than in the remainder of Imperial Russia. They had more schools and a greater proportion of their children went to school. In addition to agriculture, which (with the exception of the Tisuri Cossacks) was sufficient to supply their needs and usually to left a certain surplus, they carried on extensive cattle and horse breeding, vine culture in [[Caucasus]], fishing on the Don, the Ural, and the [[Caspian Sea]], hunting, bee-culture, etc. The extraction of coal, gold and other minerals found on their territories was mostly rented to strangers, who also owned most factories.

A military organization similar to that of the Cossacks was also introduced into certain districts, which supplied a number of mounted infantry [[sotnia]]s ("hundreds"). Their peace-footing on the eve of World War I was as follows: 

* [[Daghestan]], six regular squadrons and three of militia.
* [[Kuban]] [[Circassian]]s, one sotnia.
* [[Terek]], eight sotnias.
* [[Kars]], three sotnias.
* [[Batum]], two infantry and one mounted sotnia.
* [[Turkoman]]s, three sotnias.
* In total, 25 squadrons and 2 companies.


'''Russian Revolution and Cossacks'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks at the World War Second'''

''to be written soon''

 *Vasili Glazkov claims that the data [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]], [[Iran]]ian and [[Arab]] historians support that. According to this view, by 1261, Cossacks lived in the area between the rivers [[Dniester]] and the [[Volga]] as described for the first time in Russian chronicles.</ref> specifically mentioning 948 as the year when the inhabitants of the Steppe under the leader named ''Kasak'' or ''Kazak'' routed the [[Khazars]] from the area of modern [[Kuban]] and organized a state called ''Kazakia'' or ''[[Cossackia]]''.<ref>Newland, Samuel J.(1991), ''Cossacks in the German army, 1941-1945'', p. 65. [[Routledge]], {{ISBN|0-7146-3351-8}}</ref>
 
 Some historians suggest that the Cossack people were of mixed ethnic origins, descending from [[Turkish people|Turks]], [[Tatars]], [[Russians]], [[Ukrainians]] and others who settled or passed through the vast Steppe that stretches from Asia to southern Europe.<ref name=Newland>Samuel J Newland, ''Cossacks in the German Army, 1941-1945'', Routledge, 1991, {{ISBN|0-7146-3351-8}}</ref>

llm_output:
Removed a sentence regarding the Cossacks' origins, specifically the mention of "Khazar origin" and the context surrounding it.

Not Weaponised. The change appears to be a reversion to a previous version without introducing any specific narratives or terms that could be considered weaponised. The content remains focused on historical theories without aligning with any particular political agenda.

 *Vasili Glazkov claims that the data [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]], [[Iran]]ian and [[Arab]] historians support that. According to this view, by 1261, Cossacks lived in the area between the rivers [[Dniester]] and the [[Volga]] as described for the first time in Russian chronicles.</ref> specifically mentioning 948 as the year when the inhabitants of the Steppe under the leader named ''Kasak'' or ''Kazak'' routed the [[Khazars]] from the area of modern [[Kuban]] and organized a state called ''Kazakia'' or ''[[Cossackia]]''.<ref>Newland, Samuel J.(1991), ''Cossacks in the German army, 1941-1945'', p. 65. [[Routledge]], {{ISBN|0-7146-3351-8}}</ref>
 
 Mainly Cossacks were East Slavs, especially Russian and Ukrainian people.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Cossack|title=Cossack {{!}} Russian and Ukrainian people|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2018-08-24|language=en}}</ref> In the 15th century, the term originally described semi-independent Tatar groups which lived on the Dniepr River, which flows through [[Ukraine]], [[Russia]] and [[Belarus|Belarusia]].
 
-Some historians suggest that the Cossack people were of mixed ethnic origins, descending from [[Russians]], [[Khazars]] [[Turkish people|Turks]], [[Ukrainians|Ukrainians]] [[Tatars]], and others who settled or passed through the vast Steppe that stretches from Asia to southern Europe.<ref name="Newland">Samuel J Newland, ''Cossacks in the German Army, 1941-1945'', Routledge, 1991, {{ISBN|0-7146-3351-8}}</ref> 
+Some historians suggest that the Cossack people were of mixed ethnic origins, descending from [[Russians]], [[Khazars]] [[Turkish people|Turks]], [[Ukrainians]] [[Tatars]], and others who settled or passed through the vast Steppe that stretches from Asia to southern Europe.<ref name="Newland">Samuel J Newland, ''Cossacks in the German Army, 1941-1945'', Routledge, 1991, {{ISBN|0-7146-3351-8}}</ref> 
 
 Cossacks and their quasi-states such as the [[Zaporozhian Sich]] are considered to be responsible for nation-forming processes leading to the establishment of modern Ukrainian nation. 
 
@@ -47,7 +47,7 @@
 
 [[File:Matejko_Khmelnytsky_with_Tugay_Bey.jpg|200px|right|thumb|"[[Bohdan Khmelnytsky]] with [[Tugay Bey]] at [[Lviv]]", oil on canvas, 1885, National Museum in [[Warsaw]]. [[Khmelnytsky Uprising]] 1648-1654. Painted by [[Jan Matejko]] ]]
 
-After 1624 the Zaporozhian raids gradually died out, as the Cossacks began to devote more and more of their martial energies to land-based campaigns, fighting on one side and then the other during such conflicts as the [[Thirty Years' War]]. Their numbers expanded with  immigration from Poland proper and Lithuania. [[Szlachta]] failure to regard Zaporozhian Cossacks as nobles for inclusion in the registry of professional military cossacks eroded the Cossacks' loyalty towards the Commonwealth. The Cossack attempts to be recognized as equal to the szlachta were rebuffed and plans for transforming the Two-Nations Commonwealth (Polish–Lithuanian) into [[Polish–Lithuanian–Ruthenian Commonwealth|Three Nations]] (with Cossacks/Ruthenian people) were limited to a minority view. After the civil war of 1648 (or Rebellion from the Polish viewpoint) the [[Zaporozhian Host]] gained control of parts of Ukraine in 1649, although they at various time acknowledged the Polish King over the following decades.
+After 1624 the Zaporozhian raids gradually died out, as the Cossacks began to devote more and more of their martial energies to land-based campaigns, fighting on one side and then the other during such conflicts as the [[Thirty Years' War]]. Their numbers expanded with immigration from Poland proper and Lithuania. [[Szlachta]] failure to regard Zaporozhian Cossacks as nobles for inclusion in the registry of professional military cossacks eroded the Cossacks' loyalty towards the Commonwealth. The Cossack attempts to be recognized as equal to the szlachta were rebuffed and plans for transforming the Two-Nations Commonwealth (Polish–Lithuanian) into [[Polish–Lithuanian–Ruthenian Commonwealth|Three Nations]] (with Cossacks/Ruthenian people) were limited to a minority view. After the civil war of 1648 (or Rebellion from the Polish viewpoint) the [[Zaporozhian Host]] gained control of parts of Ukraine in 1649, although they at various time acknowledged the Polish King over the following decades.
 
 There were several Cossack uprisings against the Commonwealth in the early 17th century. The largest of them was the [[Khmelnytsky Uprising]], which together with [[Deluge (history)|The Deluge]] is considered as one of the events that brought an end to the Golden Age of the Commonwealth. This uprising distanced Cossacks from the Commonwealth sphere of influence, only to make them subject to the [[Tsardom of Russia]] under the [[Treaty of Pereyaslav]] (1654), and established their realm as [[Left-bank Ukraine]] in 1667 under the [[Treaty of Andrusovo]], and the [[Eternal Peace Treaty of 1686]].

'''History of Cossacks'''


'''Beginigs of Cossacks'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks in Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth'''

''to be written''

'''Chmielnicki's Uprising'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks in Imperial Russia'''

In the Russian Empire the Cossacks constituted ten separate [[voisko]]s, settled along the frontiers: [[Don River, Russia|Don]], [[Kuban]], [[Terek]], [[Astrakhan]], [[Ural]], [[Orenburg]], [[Siberia]]n, [[Semiryechensk]], [[Amur]], and [[Ussuri]] voiskos. The primary unit of this organization was the ''stanitsa'', or village, which held its land as a commune, and might allow persons who were not Cossacks (excepting Jews) to settle on this land for payment of a certain rent. The assembly of all householders in villages of less than 30 households, and of 30 elected men in villages having from 30 to 300 households (one from each 10 households in the more populous ones), constituted the village assembly, similar to the [[mir (social)|mir]], but having wider attributes, which assessed the taxes, divided the land, took measures for the opening and support of schools, village grain-stores, communal cultivation, and so on, and elected its ataman (elder) and its judges, who settled all disputes up to an amount that the 1911 ''Encyclopedia Britannica'' gives as "£10" (or above that sum with the consent of both sides). 

Military service was obligatory for all men, for 20 years, beginning at the age of 18. The first 3 years were passed in the preliminary division, the next 12 in active service, and the last five years in the reserve. Every Cossack was bound to procure his own uniform, equipment and horse (if mounted), the government supplying only the arms. Those on active service were divided into three equal parts according to age, and only the first third (approxiately age 18-26) were normally in active service, while the rest were effectively reserves based at home but bound to march out as soon as an order was given. The officers were supplied by the military schools, in which all Cossack voiskos had their own vacancies, or were non-commissioned Cossack officers, with officers' grades. In return for this service the Cossacks received from the state considerable grants of land for each voisko separately.

The total Cossack population in [[1893]] was 2,648,049 (including 1,331,470 women), and they owned nearly 146,500,000 acres of land, of which 105,000,000 acres were arable and 9,400,000 under forests. This land was divided between the stanitsas, at the rate of 81 acres per each soul, with special grants to officers (personal to some of them, in lieu of pensions), and leaving about one-third of the land as a reserve for the future. The income which the Cossack voiskos received from the lands which they rent to different persons, also from various sources (trade patents, rents of shops, fisheries, permits of gold-digging, etc.), as also from the subsidies they received from the government (about £712,500 in [[1893]]), was used to cover all the expenses of state and local administration. They had, besides, a special reserve capital of about £2,600,000. The expenditure of the village administration was covered by village taxes. The general administration was kept separately for each voisko, and differed with the different voiskos. The central administration, at the Ministry of War, was composed of representatives of each voisko, who discussed the proposals of all new laws affecting the Cossacks. 

In time of war the ten Cossack voiskos were bound to supply 890 mounted sotnias or squadrons (of 125 men each), 108 infantry sotnias or companies (also 125 men each), and 236 guns, representing 4267 officers and 177,100 men, with 170,695 horses. In time of peace they kept 314 squadrons, 54 infantry sotnias, and 20 batteries containing 108 guns (2574 officers, 60,532 men, 50,054 horses). Altogether, on the eve of [[World War I]] the Cossacks had 328,705 men ready to take arms. 

As a rule, popular education amongst the Cossacks stood at a higher level than in the remainder of Imperial Russia. They had more schools and a greater proportion of their children went to school. In addition to agriculture, which (with the exception of the Tisuri Cossacks) was sufficient to supply their needs and usually to left a certain surplus, they carried on extensive cattle and horse breeding, vine culture in [[Caucasus]], fishing on the Don, the Ural, and the [[Caspian Sea]], hunting, bee-culture, etc. The extraction of coal, gold and other minerals found on their territories was mostly rented to strangers, who also owned most factories.

A military organization similar to that of the Cossacks was also introduced into certain districts, which supplied a number of mounted infantry [[sotnia]]s ("hundreds"). Their peace-footing on the eve of World War I was as follows: 

* [[Daghestan]], six regular squadrons and three of militia.
* [[Kuban]] [[Circassian]]s, one sotnia.
* [[Terek]], eight sotnias.
* [[Kars]], three sotnias.
* [[Batum]], two infantry and one mounted sotnia.
* [[Turkoman]]s, three sotnias.
* In total, 25 squadrons and 2 companies.


'''Russian Revolution and Cossacks'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks at the World War Second'''

''to be written soon''

According to this view, by 1261, Cossacks lived in the area between the rivers [[Dniester]] and the [[Volga]] as described for the first time in Russian chronicles.</ref> specifically mentioning 948 as the year when the inhabitants of the Steppe under the leader named ''Kasak'' or ''Kazak'' routed the [[Khazars]] from the area of modern [[Kuban]] and organized a state called ''Kazakia'' or ''[[Cossackia]]''.<ref>Newland, Samuel J.(1991), ''Cossacks in the German army, 1941-1945'', p. 65. [[Routledge]], {{ISBN|0-7146-3351-8}}</ref>

+Mainly Cossacks were [[ Crimean Goths]] and [[East Slavs]], especially Russian and Ukrainian people.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Cossack|title=Cossack {{!}} Russian and Ukrainian people|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2018-08-24|language=en}}</ref> In the 15th century, the term originally described semi-independent Tatar groups which lived on the Dniepr River, which flows through [[Ukraine]], [[Russia]] and [[Belarus|Belarusia]].

'''History of Cossacks'''


'''Beginigs of Cossacks'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks in Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth'''

''to be written''

'''Chmielnicki's Uprising'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks in Imperial Russia'''

In the Russian Empire the Cossacks constituted ten separate [[voisko]]s, settled along the frontiers: [[Don River, Russia|Don]], [[Kuban]], [[Terek]], [[Astrakhan]], [[Ural]], [[Orenburg]], [[Siberia]]n, [[Semiryechensk]], [[Amur]], and [[Ussuri]] voiskos. The primary unit of this organization was the ''stanitsa'', or village, which held its land as a commune, and might allow persons who were not Cossacks (excepting Jews) to settle on this land for payment of a certain rent. The assembly of all householders in villages of less than 30 households, and of 30 elected men in villages having from 30 to 300 households (one from each 10 households in the more populous ones), constituted the village assembly, similar to the [[mir (social)|mir]], but having wider attributes, which assessed the taxes, divided the land, took measures for the opening and support of schools, village grain-stores, communal cultivation, and so on, and elected its ataman (elder) and its judges, who settled all disputes up to an amount that the 1911 ''Encyclopedia Britannica'' gives as "£10" (or above that sum with the consent of both sides). 

Military service was obligatory for all men, for 20 years, beginning at the age of 18. The first 3 years were passed in the preliminary division, the next 12 in active service, and the last five years in the reserve. Every Cossack was bound to procure his own uniform, equipment and horse (if mounted), the government supplying only the arms. Those on active service were divided into three equal parts according to age, and only the first third (approxiately age 18-26) were normally in active service, while the rest were effectively reserves based at home but bound to march out as soon as an order was given. The officers were supplied by the military schools, in which all Cossack voiskos had their own vacancies, or were non-commissioned Cossack officers, with officers' grades. In return for this service the Cossacks received from the state considerable grants of land for each voisko separately.

The total Cossack population in [[1893]] was 2,648,049 (including 1,331,470 women), and they owned nearly 146,500,000 acres of land, of which 105,000,000 acres were arable and 9,400,000 under forests. This land was divided between the stanitsas, at the rate of 81 acres per each soul, with special grants to officers (personal to some of them, in lieu of pensions), and leaving about one-third of the land as a reserve for the future. The income which the Cossack voiskos received from the lands which they rent to different persons, also from various sources (trade patents, rents of shops, fisheries, permits of gold-digging, etc.), as also from the subsidies they received from the government (about £712,500 in [[1893]]), was used to cover all the expenses of state and local administration. They had, besides, a special reserve capital of about £2,600,000. The expenditure of the village administration was covered by village taxes. The general administration was kept separately for each voisko, and differed with the different voiskos. The central administration, at the Ministry of War, was composed of representatives of each voisko, who discussed the proposals of all new laws affecting the Cossacks. 

In time of war the ten Cossack voiskos were bound to supply 890 mounted sotnias or squadrons (of 125 men each), 108 infantry sotnias or companies (also 125 men each), and 236 guns, representing 4267 officers and 177,100 men, with 170,695 horses. In time of peace they kept 314 squadrons, 54 infantry sotnias, and 20 batteries containing 108 guns (2574 officers, 60,532 men, 50,054 horses). Altogether, on the eve of [[World War I]] the Cossacks had 328,705 men ready to take arms. 

As a rule, popular education amongst the Cossacks stood at a higher level than in the remainder of Imperial Russia. They had more schools and a greater proportion of their children went to school. In addition to agriculture, which (with the exception of the Tisuri Cossacks) was sufficient to supply their needs and usually to left a certain surplus, they carried on extensive cattle and horse breeding, vine culture in [[Caucasus]], fishing on the Don, the Ural, and the [[Caspian Sea]], hunting, bee-culture, etc. The extraction of coal, gold and other minerals found on their territories was mostly rented to strangers, who also owned most factories.

A military organization similar to that of the Cossacks was also introduced into certain districts, which supplied a number of mounted infantry [[sotnia]]s ("hundreds"). Their peace-footing on the eve of World War I was as follows: 

* [[Daghestan]], six regular squadrons and three of militia.
* [[Kuban]] [[Circassian]]s, one sotnia.
* [[Terek]], eight sotnias.
* [[Kars]], three sotnias.
* [[Batum]], two infantry and one mounted sotnia.
* [[Turkoman]]s, three sotnias.
* In total, 25 squadrons and 2 companies.


'''Russian Revolution and Cossacks'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks at the World War Second'''

''to be written soon''

**Weaponised**: The revision subtly shifts the narrative to emphasize a specific ethnic lineage (Crimean Goths and Alans) over others (Khazars), which can be interpreted as an attempt to reshape historical identity and heritage in a way that may serve political or cultural agendas. This aligns with the broader context of cultural heritage weaponization, where historical narratives are manipulated to support contemporary claims or identities.

The history of Russian life. http://az.lib.ru/z/zabelin_i_e/text_0050.shtml</ref> not only [[Crimean Goths]], which assimilated/included [[Severians]], [[Alans]], [[Scythians]] and other ancient inhabitants, as insisted by the Cossack folklore, the Constitution of Pylyp Orlik, and numerous Cossack historians. '''History of Cossacks'''


'''Beginigs of Cossacks'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks in Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth'''

''to be written''

'''Chmielnicki's Uprising'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks in Imperial Russia'''

In the Russian Empire the Cossacks constituted ten separate [[voisko]]s, settled along the frontiers: [[Don River, Russia|Don]], [[Kuban]], [[Terek]], [[Astrakhan]], [[Ural]], [[Orenburg]], [[Siberia]]n, [[Semiryechensk]], [[Amur]], and [[Ussuri]] voiskos. The primary unit of this organization was the ''stanitsa'', or village, which held its land as a commune, and might allow persons who were not Cossacks (excepting Jews) to settle on this land for payment of a certain rent. The assembly of all householders in villages of less than 30 households, and of 30 elected men in villages having from 30 to 300 households (one from each 10 households in the more populous ones), constituted the village assembly, similar to the [[mir (social)|mir]], but having wider attributes, which assessed the taxes, divided the land, took measures for the opening and support of schools, village grain-stores, communal cultivation, and so on, and elected its ataman (elder) and its judges, who settled all disputes up to an amount that the 1911 ''Encyclopedia Britannica'' gives as "£10" (or above that sum with the consent of both sides). 

Military service was obligatory for all men, for 20 years, beginning at the age of 18. The first 3 years were passed in the preliminary division, the next 12 in active service, and the last five years in the reserve. Every Cossack was bound to procure his own uniform, equipment and horse (if mounted), the government supplying only the arms. Those on active service were divided into three equal parts according to age, and only the first third (approxiately age 18-26) were normally in active service, while the rest were effectively reserves based at home but bound to march out as soon as an order was given. The officers were supplied by the military schools, in which all Cossack voiskos had their own vacancies, or were non-commissioned Cossack officers, with officers' grades. In return for this service the Cossacks received from the state considerable grants of land for each voisko separately.

The total Cossack population in [[1893]] was 2,648,049 (including 1,331,470 women), and they owned nearly 146,500,000 acres of land, of which 105,000,000 acres were arable and 9,400,000 under forests. This land was divided between the stanitsas, at the rate of 81 acres per each soul, with special grants to officers (personal to some of them, in lieu of pensions), and leaving about one-third of the land as a reserve for the future. The income which the Cossack voiskos received from the lands which they rent to different persons, also from various sources (trade patents, rents of shops, fisheries, permits of gold-digging, etc.), as also from the subsidies they received from the government (about £712,500 in [[1893]]), was used to cover all the expenses of state and local administration. They had, besides, a special reserve capital of about £2,600,000. The expenditure of the village administration was covered by village taxes. The general administration was kept separately for each voisko, and differed with the different voiskos. The central administration, at the Ministry of War, was composed of representatives of each voisko, who discussed the proposals of all new laws affecting the Cossacks. 

In time of war the ten Cossack voiskos were bound to supply 890 mounted sotnias or squadrons (of 125 men each), 108 infantry sotnias or companies (also 125 men each), and 236 guns, representing 4267 officers and 177,100 men, with 170,695 horses. In time of peace they kept 314 squadrons, 54 infantry sotnias, and 20 batteries containing 108 guns (2574 officers, 60,532 men, 50,054 horses). Altogether, on the eve of [[World War I]] the Cossacks had 328,705 men ready to take arms. 

As a rule, popular education amongst the Cossacks stood at a higher level than in the remainder of Imperial Russia. They had more schools and a greater proportion of their children went to school. In addition to agriculture, which (with the exception of the Tisuri Cossacks) was sufficient to supply their needs and usually to left a certain surplus, they carried on extensive cattle and horse breeding, vine culture in [[Caucasus]], fishing on the Don, the Ural, and the [[Caspian Sea]], hunting, bee-culture, etc. The extraction of coal, gold and other minerals found on their territories was mostly rented to strangers, who also owned most factories.

A military organization similar to that of the Cossacks was also introduced into certain districts, which supplied a number of mounted infantry [[sotnia]]s ("hundreds"). Their peace-footing on the eve of World War I was as follows: 

* [[Daghestan]], six regular squadrons and three of militia.
* [[Kuban]] [[Circassian]]s, one sotnia.
* [[Terek]], eight sotnias.
* [[Kars]], three sotnias.
* [[Batum]], two infantry and one mounted sotnia.
* [[Turkoman]]s, three sotnias.
* In total, 25 squadrons and 2 companies.


'''Russian Revolution and Cossacks'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks at the World War Second'''

''to be written soon''
llm_output:
Removed multiple issue templates related to missing information and the need for updates.

Not Weaponised. The changes are administrative in nature, focusing on the formatting and organization of the article rather than introducing any specific cultural narratives or perspectives that could be weaponized.

initial_version:
'''History of Cossacks'''


'''Beginigs of Cossacks'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks in Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth'''

''to be written''

'''Chmielnicki's Uprising'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks in Imperial Russia'''

In the Russian Empire the Cossacks constituted ten separate [[voisko]]s, settled along the frontiers: [[Don River, Russia|Don]], [[Kuban]], [[Terek]], [[Astrakhan]], [[Ural]], [[Orenburg]], [[Siberia]]n, [[Semiryechensk]], [[Amur]], and [[Ussuri]] voiskos. The primary unit of this organization was the ''stanitsa'', or village, which held its land as a commune, and might allow persons who were not Cossacks (excepting Jews) to settle on this land for payment of a certain rent. The assembly of all householders in villages of less than 30 households, and of 30 elected men in villages having from 30 to 300 households (one from each 10 households in the more populous ones), constituted the village assembly, similar to the [[mir (social)|mir]], but having wider attributes, which assessed the taxes, divided the land, took measures for the opening and support of schools, village grain-stores, communal cultivation, and so on, and elected its ataman (elder) and its judges, who settled all disputes up to an amount that the 1911 ''Encyclopedia Britannica'' gives as "£10" (or above that sum with the consent of both sides). 

Military service was obligatory for all men, for 20 years, beginning at the age of 18. The first 3 years were passed in the preliminary division, the next 12 in active service, and the last five years in the reserve. Every Cossack was bound to procure his own uniform, equipment and horse (if mounted), the government supplying only the arms. Those on active service were divided into three equal parts according to age, and only the first third (approxiately age 18-26) were normally in active service, while the rest were effectively reserves based at home but bound to march out as soon as an order was given. The officers were supplied by the military schools, in which all Cossack voiskos had their own vacancies, or were non-commissioned Cossack officers, with officers' grades. In return for this service the Cossacks received from the state considerable grants of land for each voisko separately.

The total Cossack population in [[1893]] was 2,648,049 (including 1,331,470 women), and they owned nearly 146,500,000 acres of land, of which 105,000,000 acres were arable and 9,400,000 under forests. This land was divided between the stanitsas, at the rate of 81 acres per each soul, with special grants to officers (personal to some of them, in lieu of pensions), and leaving about one-third of the land as a reserve for the future. The income which the Cossack voiskos received from the lands which they rent to different persons, also from various sources (trade patents, rents of shops, fisheries, permits of gold-digging, etc.), as also from the subsidies they received from the government (about £712,500 in [[1893]]), was used to cover all the expenses of state and local administration. They had, besides, a special reserve capital of about £2,600,000. The expenditure of the village administration was covered by village taxes. The general administration was kept separately for each voisko, and differed with the different voiskos. The central administration, at the Ministry of War, was composed of representatives of each voisko, who discussed the proposals of all new laws affecting the Cossacks. 

In time of war the ten Cossack voiskos were bound to supply 890 mounted sotnias or squadrons (of 125 men each), 108 infantry sotnias or companies (also 125 men each), and 236 guns, representing 4267 officers and 177,100 men, with 170,695 horses. In time of peace they kept 314 squadrons, 54 infantry sotnias, and 20 batteries containing 108 guns (2574 officers, 60,532 men, 50,054 horses). Altogether, on the eve of [[World War I]] the Cossacks had 328,705 men ready to take arms. 

As a rule, popular education amongst the Cossacks stood at a higher level than in the remainder of Imperial Russia. They had more schools and a greater proportion of their children went to school. In addition to agriculture, which (with the exception of the Tisuri Cossacks) was sufficient to supply their needs and usually to left a certain surplus, they carried on extensive cattle and horse breeding, vine culture in [[Caucasus]], fishing on the Don, the Ural, and the [[Caspian Sea]], hunting, bee-culture, etc. The extraction of coal, gold and other minerals found on their territories was mostly rented to strangers, who also owned most factories.

A military organization similar to that of the Cossacks was also introduced into certain districts, which supplied a number of mounted infantry [[sotnia]]s ("hundreds"). Their peace-footing on the eve of World War I was as follows: 

* [[Daghestan]], six regular squadrons and three of militia.
* [[Kuban]] [[Circassian]]s, one sotnia.
* [[Terek]], eight sotnias.
* [[Kars]], three sotnias.
* [[Batum]], two infantry and one mounted sotnia.
* [[Turkoman]]s, three sotnias.
* In total, 25 squadrons and 2 companies.


'''Russian Revolution and Cossacks'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks at the World War Second'''

''to be written soon''
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -57,7 +57,7 @@
 There were several Cossack uprisings against the Commonwealth in the early 17th century. The largest of them was the [[Khmelnytsky Uprising]], which together with [[Deluge (history)|The Deluge]] is considered as one of the events that brought an end to the Golden Age of the Commonwealth. This uprising distanced Cossacks from the Commonwealth sphere of influence, only to make them subject to the [[Tsardom of Russia]] under the [[Treaty of Pereyaslav]] (1654), and established their realm as [[Left-bank Ukraine]] in 1667 under the [[Treaty of Andrusovo]], and the [[Eternal Peace Treaty of 1686]].
 
 ==Ukraine and Tsarist Russia==
-After this point, the Cossack nation of the Zaporozhian Host was divided into two semiautonomous republics within the [[Tsardom of Russia|Tsarist Russian state]]: the [[Cossack Hetmanate|Hetmanate]] on the Dnieper's left bank, and the more independent [[Zaporozhia]] to the south. A Cossack organization was also established in the Russian colony of [[Sloboda Ukraine]]. 
+After this point, the Cossack nation of the Zaporozhian Host was divided into two semiautonomous republics within the [[Tsardom of Russia|Russian state]]: the [[Cossack Hetmanate|Hetmanate]] on the Dnieper's left bank, and the more independent [[Zaporozhia]] to the south. A Cossack organization was also established in the Russian colony of [[Sloboda Ukraine]]. 
 
 These organizations gradually lost their independence, and were abolished by [[Catherine the Great|Catherine II]] by the late 18th century. The Hetmanate became the governorship of [[Little Russia]], and Sloboda Ukraine the [[Kharkiv province]]. After having its capital, the [[Zaporozhian Sich|Sich]], similar to Ukrainian capitals [[Chigirin]] and [[Baturyn]] destroyed and relocated more than once, Zaporozhia was absorbed into [[New Russia]].
comment: /* Ukraine and Tsarist Russia */ ce - Overlooked having added 'Tsarist' to the actual text when changing wl. Redundant over-qualification for the context.
llm_output:
Changed "Tsarist Russian state" to "Russian state".

**Not Weaponised**: The change is a simplification of terminology without introducing any charged or politically sensitive language. It does not reflect a shift towards weaponizing cultural heritage.

In the Russian Empire the Cossacks constituted ten separate [[voisko]]s, settled along the frontiers: [[Don River, Russia|Don]], [[Kuban]], [[Terek]], [[Astrakhan]], [[Ural]], [[Orenburg]], [[Siberia]]n, [[Semiryechensk]], [[Amur]], and [[Ussuri]] voiskos. The assembly of all householders in villages of less than 30 households, and of 30 elected men in villages having from 30 to 300 households (one from each 10 households in the more populous ones), constituted the village assembly, similar to the [[mir (social)|mir]], but having wider attributes, which assessed the taxes, divided the land, took measures for the opening and support of schools, village grain-stores, communal cultivation, and so on, and elected its ataman (elder) and its judges, who settled all disputes up to an amount that the 1911 ''Encyclopedia Britannica'' gives as "£10" (or above that sum with the consent of both sides). 

Military service was obligatory for all men, for 20 years, beginning at the age of 18. The first 3 years were passed in the preliminary division, the next 12 in active service, and the last five years in the reserve. Every Cossack was bound to procure his own uniform, equipment and horse (if mounted), the government supplying only the arms. Those on active service were divided into three equal parts according to age, and only the first third (approxiately age 18-26) were normally in active service, while the rest were effectively reserves based at home but bound to march out as soon as an order was given. The officers were supplied by the military schools, in which all Cossack voiskos had their own vacancies, or were non-commissioned Cossack officers, with officers' grades. In return for this service the Cossacks received from the state considerable grants of land for each voisko separately.

The total Cossack population in [[1893]] was 2,648,049 (including 1,331,470 women), and they owned nearly 146,500,000 acres of land, of which 105,000,000 acres were arable and 9,400,000 under forests. This land was divided between the stanitsas, at the rate of 81 acres per each soul, with special grants to officers (personal to some of them, in lieu of pensions), and leaving about one-third of the land as a reserve for the future. The income which the Cossack voiskos received from the lands which they rent to different persons, also from various sources (trade patents, rents of shops, fisheries, permits of gold-digging, etc.), as also from the subsidies they received from the government (about £712,500 in [[1893]]), was used to cover all the expenses of state and local administration. They had, besides, a special reserve capital of about £2,600,000. The expenditure of the village administration was covered by village taxes. The general administration was kept separately for each voisko, and differed with the different voiskos. The central administration, at the Ministry of War, was composed of representatives of each voisko, who discussed the proposals of all new laws affecting the Cossacks. 

In time of war the ten Cossack voiskos were bound to supply 890 mounted sotnias or squadrons (of 125 men each), 108 infantry sotnias or companies (also 125 men each), and 236 guns, representing 4267 officers and 177,100 men, with 170,695 horses. In time of peace they kept 314 squadrons, 54 infantry sotnias, and 20 batteries containing 108 guns (2574 officers, 60,532 men, 50,054 horses). Altogether, on the eve of [[World War I]] the Cossacks had 328,705 men ready to take arms. 

As a rule, popular education amongst the Cossacks stood at a higher level than in the remainder of Imperial Russia. They had more schools and a greater proportion of their children went to school. In addition to agriculture, which (with the exception of the Tisuri Cossacks) was sufficient to supply their needs and usually to left a certain surplus, they carried on extensive cattle and horse breeding, vine culture in [[Caucasus]], fishing on the Don, the Ural, and the [[Caspian Sea]], hunting, bee-culture, etc. The extraction of coal, gold and other minerals found on their territories was mostly rented to strangers, who also owned most factories.

A military organization similar to that of the Cossacks was also introduced into certain districts, which supplied a number of mounted infantry [[sotnia]]s ("hundreds"). Their peace-footing on the eve of World War I was as follows: 

* [[Daghestan]], six regular squadrons and three of militia.
* [[Kuban]] [[Circassian]]s, one sotnia.
* [[Terek]], eight sotnias.
* [[Kars]], three sotnias.
* [[Batum]], two infantry and one mounted sotnia.
* [[Turkoman]]s, three sotnias.
* In total, 25 squadrons and 2 companies.


'''Russian Revolution and Cossacks'''

''to be written''

'''Cossacks at the World War Second'''

''to be written soon''

comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/Илон Ривс Маск|Илон Ривс Маск]] ([[User talk:Илон Ривс Маск|talk]]): Rv ([[WP:TW|TW]])
llm_output:
The change made is a **rephrasing** of the text regarding the origins of the Cossacks, specifically altering the mention of "Crimean Goths" to "Khazar" origin in the context of historical theories.

**Weaponised**: The revision subtly shifts the narrative focus from a broader historical context (including "Crimean Goths") to a more specific ethnic origin ("Khazar"), which can be interpreted as an attempt to align with a particular nationalistic narrative that emphasizes Turkic roots over Slavic ones. This can be seen as an effort to influence perceptions of cultural heritage in a politically charged context.
